### Subsection: 11.1c Evaluating Retrofitting Options

When considering retrofitting options for carbon dioxide capture, it is important to evaluate each option based on a set of criteria. These criteria may include cost, efficiency, reliability, and environmental impact. By evaluating each option against these criteria, engineers can make an informed decision about which retrofitting option is the most suitable for their specific needs and constraints.

#### 11.1c.1 Cost

The cost of a retrofitting option is a crucial factor to consider. The cost of implementing a retrofitting option may include the cost of equipment, installation, and maintenance. It is important to consider the long-term costs as well, such as the cost of operating the equipment and the cost of disposing of any waste products. By evaluating the cost of each option, engineers can determine which option is the most financially feasible.

#### 11.1c.2 Efficiency

The efficiency of a retrofitting option refers to how well it can capture and remove carbon dioxide from a system. This is an important factor to consider, as the goal of retrofitting is to reduce carbon dioxide emissions. By evaluating the efficiency of each option, engineers can determine which option is the most effective at capturing and removing carbon dioxide.

#### 11.1c.3 Reliability

The reliability of a retrofitting option refers to how likely it is to function properly and consistently. This is an important factor to consider, as a reliable option is crucial for ensuring the effectiveness of carbon dioxide capture. By evaluating the reliability of each option, engineers can determine which option is the most trustworthy and reliable.

#### 11.1c.4 Environmental Impact

The environmental impact of a retrofitting option refers to its impact on the environment. This includes considerations such as energy consumption, waste production, and potential environmental hazards. By evaluating the environmental impact of each option, engineers can determine which option has the least negative impact on the environment.

By evaluating each retrofitting option against these criteria, engineers can make an informed decision about which option is the most suitable for their specific needs and constraints. This evaluation process is crucial for ensuring the success and effectiveness of carbon dioxide capture retrofitting.

### Subsection: 11.2a Basics of Amine Stripping

Amine stripping is a crucial process in the chemical industry, used for the removal of acid gases such as hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and carbon dioxide (CO2) from gas streams. This process involves the use of amines, which are organic compounds with a nitrogen atom and one or more carbon atoms. The amines used in this process are typically monoethanolamine (MEA), diethanolamine (DEA), and triethanolamine (TEA).

The basic principle behind amine stripping is the use of a chemical reaction to remove acid gases from a gas stream. The amine molecules react with the acid gases, forming a salt-like compound that is more soluble in the amine solution. This allows for the easy separation of the acid gases from the gas stream.

The amine stripping process can be divided into three main stages: absorption, reaction, and stripping. In the absorption stage, the amine solution is contacted with the gas stream, allowing the acid gases to react with the amine molecules. In the reaction stage, the amine molecules react with the acid gases to form the salt-like compounds. Finally, in the stripping stage, the amine solution is contacted with a stream of hot gas, causing the salt-like compounds to break down and release the acid gases.

The efficiency of amine stripping is influenced by several factors, including the type of amine used, the operating conditions, and the design of the stripping unit. The type of amine used can greatly affect the efficiency of the process, as different amines have different affinities for different acid gases. The operating conditions, such as temperature and pressure, can also impact the efficiency of the process. Additionally, the design of the stripping unit, including the size and configuration of the contactor and the stripping section, can greatly affect the efficiency of the process.

In the next section, we will discuss the different types of amine stripping units and their advantages and disadvantages.

### Subsection: 11.2b Types of Amine Stripping Units

There are several types of amine stripping units used in the chemical industry, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. These include the matrix, internal exchange, flashing feed, and multipressure with split feed configurations.

#### Matrix

The matrix configuration is the most commonly used type of amine stripping unit. In this configuration, the amine solution is contacted with the gas stream in a packed bed of solid material, such as Raschig rings or Berl saddles. The solid material provides a large surface area for the reaction to occur, increasing the efficiency of the process. However, this configuration can be prone to fouling and may require frequent maintenance.

#### Internal Exchange

The internal exchange configuration involves the use of a second amine solution, known as the lean amine, to strip the acid gases from the rich amine solution. The lean amine is contacted with the gas stream, allowing the acid gases to react with the amine molecules. The resulting rich amine solution is then contacted with the lean amine solution, causing the acid gases to be transferred from one solution to the other. This configuration can be more energy-efficient than the matrix configuration, but it also requires additional equipment and control.

#### Flashing Feed

The flashing feed configuration involves the use of a flash vessel to separate the amine solution into a liquid phase and a vapor phase. The liquid phase is contacted with the gas stream, while the vapor phase is contacted with a stream of hot gas. This configuration can be more energy-efficient than the matrix and internal exchange configurations, but it also requires additional equipment and control.

#### Multipressure with Split Feed

The multipressure with split feed configuration involves the use of multiple pressure levels to improve the efficiency of the stripping process. The amine solution is split into two streams, one at a higher pressure and one at a lower pressure. The higher pressure stream is contacted with the gas stream, while the lower pressure stream is contacted with a stream of hot gas. This configuration can be more energy-efficient than the other configurations, but it also requires additional equipment and control.

In the next section, we will discuss the design considerations for amine stripping units and how to optimize the process for different applications.

### Subsection: 11.2c Applications of Amine Stripping

Amine stripping units have a wide range of applications in the chemical industry. They are commonly used for the removal of acid gases, such as hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and carbon dioxide (CO2), from gas streams. These acid gases can be corrosive and toxic, making their removal essential for the safe and efficient operation of chemical processes.

#### Hydrogen Sulfide Removal

One of the primary applications of amine stripping units is the removal of hydrogen sulfide from gas streams. Hydrogen sulfide is a highly corrosive and toxic gas that can cause significant damage to equipment and pose a risk to workers. Amine stripping units are used to remove hydrogen sulfide from gas streams, making the gas safe for further processing or disposal.

#### Carbon Dioxide Removal

Amine stripping units are also used for the removal of carbon dioxide from gas streams. Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas and can contribute to climate change. Its removal from gas streams is essential for reducing the environmental impact of industrial processes. Amine stripping units are particularly useful for removing carbon dioxide from gas streams that also contain hydrogen sulfide, as they can remove both gases simultaneously.

#### Other Applications

In addition to the removal of acid gases, amine stripping units have other applications in the chemical industry. They are used for the recovery of amines from waste streams, for the removal of impurities from chemical reactions, and for the purification of hydrogen gas. Amine stripping units are also used in the food and beverage industry for the removal of sulfur compounds from natural gas, which can affect the flavor of products.

Overall, amine stripping units play a crucial role in the chemical industry, providing a safe and efficient means of removing acid gases and other impurities from gas streams. Their versatility and effectiveness make them an essential component of many industrial processes.

### Subsection: 11.2b Evaluating Amine Stripping Alternatives

As mentioned in the previous section, amine stripping is a crucial process in the chemical industry for the removal of acid gases from gas streams. However, there are alternative processes that can be used for this purpose, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. In this section, we will discuss some of these alternatives and evaluate their effectiveness compared to amine stripping.

#### 11.2b.1 Pressure Swing Adsorption (PSA)

Pressure Swing Adsorption (PSA) is a process that uses adsorbent materials to remove impurities from a gas stream. The process involves alternating between high and low pressure, which allows for the adsorbent material to selectively adsorb impurities from the gas stream. The adsorbed impurities can then be desorbed and removed from the system.

One of the main advantages of PSA is its ability to achieve high purity levels, making it suitable for applications where very pure gas is required. Additionally, PSA is a relatively simple and low-cost process compared to other alternatives. However, PSA is limited in its ability to remove certain impurities, such as hydrogen sulfide, and may require additional treatment steps.

#### 11.2b.2 Membrane Separation

Membrane separation is a process that uses a semi-permeable membrane to separate different components of a gas stream. The membrane is selective, allowing certain molecules to pass through while blocking others. This process is commonly used for the removal of carbon dioxide from natural gas.

One of the main advantages of membrane separation is its ability to achieve high selectivity, making it suitable for applications where specific components need to be removed from a gas stream. Additionally, membrane separation is a relatively simple and low-cost process. However, membrane separation is limited in its ability to remove certain impurities, such as hydrogen sulfide, and may require additional treatment steps.

#### 11.2b.3 Cryogenic Distillation

Cryogenic distillation is a process that uses low temperatures to separate different components of a gas stream. The process involves cooling the gas stream to a very low temperature, causing the components to condense and separate. The condensed components can then be removed and purified.

One of the main advantages of cryogenic distillation is its ability to achieve high purity levels, making it suitable for applications where very pure gas is required. Additionally, cryogenic distillation is able to remove a wide range of impurities, including hydrogen sulfide. However, cryogenic distillation is a complex and expensive process, requiring specialized equipment and operating conditions.

#### 11.2b.4 Comparison to Amine Stripping

When comparing these alternative processes to amine stripping, it is important to consider the specific requirements and limitations of each process. Amine stripping is a versatile and effective process for the removal of acid gases, but it may not be suitable for all applications. For example, PSA may be a better option for achieving high purity levels, while cryogenic distillation may be more suitable for removing a wide range of impurities.

In conclusion, there are several alternative processes that can be used for the removal of acid gases from gas streams. Each process has its own advantages and disadvantages, and the choice of process will depend on the specific requirements and limitations of the application.

#### 11.2c Case Studies in Amine Stripping

In this section, we will explore some real-world case studies that demonstrate the application of amine stripping in different industries. These case studies will provide a deeper understanding of the process and its effectiveness in removing acid gases from gas streams.

##### Case Study 1: Amine Stripping in the Oil and Gas Industry

The oil and gas industry is one of the largest consumers of amine stripping for the removal of acid gases from gas streams. In this industry, amine stripping is used to remove hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide from natural gas before it is piped to consumers. This is crucial as these impurities can corrode pipelines and equipment, making it unsafe for consumption.

One example of a successful application of amine stripping in the oil and gas industry is the use of the Girbotol process. This process, as shown in the flow diagram below, includes an absorber unit and a regenerator unit as well as accessory equipment. The absorber unit is used to absorb acid gases from the gas stream, while the regenerator unit is used to strip the absorbed gases from the amine solution. This process is highly effective in removing acid gases from natural gas, making it safe for consumption.

##### Case Study 2: Amine Stripping in the Chemical Industry

The chemical industry also heavily relies on amine stripping for the removal of acid gases from gas streams. In this industry, amine stripping is used in the production of various chemicals, such as ammonia and urea. These chemicals are produced through a process called the Haber-Bosch process, which involves the reaction of nitrogen and hydrogen gases. However, these gases often contain impurities such as hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide, which can negatively affect the production process.

To remove these impurities, amine stripping is used to absorb the acid gases from the gas stream. The absorbed gases are then stripped from the amine solution, resulting in a purified gas stream that can be used in the production process. This application of amine stripping is crucial in ensuring the efficient and safe production of chemicals.

##### Case Study 3: Amine Stripping in Power Plants

Power plants also rely on amine stripping for the removal of acid gases from gas streams. In these plants, amine stripping is used to remove sulfur dioxide from flue gas, which is a byproduct of burning fossil fuels. Sulfur dioxide is a corrosive gas that can damage plant equipment and cause environmental pollution.

One example of a successful application of amine stripping in power plants is the use of the FGD (flue gas desulfurization) process. This process involves the use of amine solutions to absorb sulfur dioxide from flue gas. The absorbed gas is then stripped from the amine solution, resulting in a purified gas stream that can be safely released into the environment. This process is crucial in reducing environmental pollution and protecting plant equipment.

In conclusion, these case studies demonstrate the versatility and effectiveness of amine stripping in various industries. From the oil and gas industry to the chemical and power industries, amine stripping plays a crucial role in the removal of acid gases from gas streams. Its applications continue to expand as new technologies and processes are developed, making it an essential process in the field of chemical engineering.

### Subsection: 12.1a Introduction to Chemical Looping Combustion

Chemical looping combustion (CLC) is a promising technology for retrofitting existing power plants, particularly those that use fossil fuels. It offers a unique approach to carbon capture, making it a potential solution to the growing concern of carbon emissions. In this section, we will provide an overview of CLC, including its principles, advantages, and potential applications.

#### Principles of Chemical Looping Combustion

CLC is a combustion process that involves the use of an oxygen carrier material to facilitate the combustion of a fuel. The oxygen carrier material, typically a metal oxide, is first reduced in a reactor by reacting with the fuel. The reduced oxygen carrier is then transported to a second reactor, where it is oxidized by atmospheric oxygen. This process results in the combustion of the fuel, with the oxygen carrier acting as a shuttle for oxygen.

The key advantage of CLC is that it allows for the separation of the combustion process from the carbon capture process. This separation is achieved by the use of the oxygen carrier material, which acts as a buffer between the fuel and the atmosphere. The two resulting flue gas streams, one from the air reactor and one from the fuel reactor, have different compositions. The air reactor flue gas is primarily composed of nitrogen, while the fuel reactor flue gas is primarily composed of carbon dioxide and water vapor. This separation allows for the efficient capture of carbon dioxide, as the fuel reactor flue gas can be easily treated to remove the carbon dioxide.

#### Advantages of Chemical Looping Combustion

One of the main advantages of CLC is its potential for near-complete carbon capture. As mentioned earlier, the fuel reactor flue gas can be treated to remove almost all of the carbon dioxide, resulting in a nearly pure stream of carbon dioxide. This is in contrast to other carbon capture technologies, which often involve a significant energy penalty or require the use of expensive materials.

Another advantage of CLC is its potential for retrofitting existing power plants. The technology can be implemented in a modular manner, making it suitable for retrofitting both large and small power plants. Additionally, the use of oxygen carrier materials allows for the flexibility to use a variety of fuels, including coal, natural gas, and biomass.

#### Applications of Chemical Looping Combustion

CLC has been successfully demonstrated in various pilot studies, with operational experience exceeding 9000 hours. It has been used for both gaseous and solid fuels, and has shown promising results in terms of efficiency and carbon capture. One notable application of CLC is the Coal Direct Chemical Looping (CDCL) process, which has been proposed as an energy-efficient carbon capture technology.

In conclusion, chemical looping combustion is a promising technology for retrofitting existing power plants. Its unique approach to carbon capture, along with its potential for flexibility and efficiency, make it a valuable tool in the fight against carbon emissions. In the following sections, we will delve deeper into the principles and applications of CLC, providing a comprehensive guide for its implementation in power plant retrofitting.





### Subsection: 12.1b Applications of Chemical Looping Combustion

Chemical looping combustion (CLC) has a wide range of potential applications in the field of chemical engineering. Its unique ability to separate the combustion process from the carbon capture process makes it a versatile technology that can be applied to various types of power plants. In this subsection, we will discuss some of the potential applications of CLC.

#### Retrofitting Existing Power Plants

One of the most promising applications of CLC is in the retrofitting of existing power plants. As mentioned in the previous section, CLC can be used to capture nearly all of the carbon dioxide generated by a power plant. This makes it a potential solution for reducing the carbon footprint of existing power plants. The technology has been successfully demonstrated in a 25 kW<sub>th</sub> CDCL sub-pilot unit, which operated for 200 hours and achieved nearly 100% coal conversion to CO<sub>2</sub> with no carbon carryover to the air reactor.

#### Coal Direct Chemical Looping (CDCL)

CDCL is a specific application of CLC that has been proposed for use in coal-fired power plants. In CDCL, the coal is directly combusted in the fuel reactor, eliminating the need for a separate fuel preparation process. This makes CDCL a more efficient and cost-effective option compared to traditional coal-fired power plants. The continuous 200-hour demonstration results of a 25 kW<sub>th</sub> CDCL sub-pilot unit have shown the potential of CDCL, with nearly 100% coal conversion to CO<sub>2</sub> and no carbon carryover to the air reactor.

#### Other Applications

Apart from retrofitting existing power plants and CDCL, CLC has other potential applications in the field of chemical engineering. It can be used in the production of hydrogen, as the oxygen carrier material can be used to oxidize hydrocarbons to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide. CLC can also be used in the production of synthetic fuels, as the oxygen carrier material can be used to reduce carbon dioxide to produce synthetic fuels. These applications demonstrate the versatility of CLC and its potential to revolutionize the field of chemical engineering.

### Conclusion

In conclusion, chemical looping combustion (CLC) is a promising technology for retrofitting existing power plants and reducing their carbon footprint. Its unique ability to separate the combustion process from the carbon capture process makes it a versatile technology that can be applied to various types of power plants. With further research and development, CLC has the potential to play a significant role in the future of sustainable energy production.





### Subsection: 12.1c Case Studies in Chemical Looping Combustion

Chemical looping combustion (CLC) has been successfully demonstrated in various pilot plants, providing valuable insights into its potential applications and limitations. In this subsection, we will discuss some of the case studies of CLC and their implications for the technology.

#### 12.1c.1 Continuous 200-hour Demonstration of CDCL

As mentioned in the previous section, a continuous 200-hour demonstration of a 25 kW<sub>th</sub> CDCL sub-pilot unit was conducted in 2010. The results of this demonstration were promising, with nearly 100% coal conversion to CO<sub>2</sub> and no carbon carryover to the air reactor. This demonstration also highlighted the potential of CDCL for retrofitting existing power plants, as it was conducted in a retrofitted coal-fired power plant.

#### 12.1c.2 Operation of CLC with Gaseous Fuels

The first operation of CLC with gaseous fuels was demonstrated in 2003, and later with solid fuels in 2006. This operation was conducted in a 0.3 MW pilot plant, and the results were encouraging. The use of gaseous fuels in CLC opens up new possibilities for the technology, as it can be applied to a wider range of power plants.

#### 12.1c.3 Technology Development

The operational experience of CLC in various pilot plants has been more than 9000 hours. This experience has been gained from operating units of 0.3 to 3 MW, providing valuable insights into the technology's performance and limitations. The use of different oxygen carrier materials, including monometallic oxides and combined oxides, has also been explored in these pilot plants.

#### 12.1c.4 Future Prospects

The successful demonstration of CLC in various pilot plants has paved the way for its commercialization. The technology's potential for retrofitting existing power plants and its ability to capture nearly all of the carbon dioxide generated make it a promising solution for reducing the carbon footprint of the power industry. Further research and development efforts are needed to optimize the technology and make it more cost-effective.




### Section: 12.2 CO2 Liquefaction:

#### 12.2a Basics of CO2 Liquefaction

Carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) liquefaction is a critical process in the retrofitting of existing power plants. It involves the conversion of CO<sub>2</sub> from flue gas into a liquid form, which can then be easily stored or transported. This process is essential for the effective capture and storage of CO<sub>2</sub>, which is a key strategy in mitigating the environmental impact of power plants.

The liquefaction of CO<sub>2</sub> is typically achieved through a process known as the Brayton cycle, which involves the use of a gas turbine and a heat exchanger. The CO<sub>2</sub> from the flue gas is first cooled and then compressed to a high pressure and low temperature. This high-pressure CO<sub>2</sub> is then expanded through a valve, causing it to cool further and liquefy. The liquid CO<sub>2</sub> is then stored or transported for further processing.

The liquefaction process is highly energy-intensive, requiring significant amounts of electricity to drive the compressors and expanders. However, the energy requirements can be reduced by using a hybrid system that combines the Brayton cycle with other methods, such as the Kalina cycle or the Rankine cycle. These hybrid systems can achieve higher efficiencies and lower energy requirements, making them more attractive for large-scale CO<sub>2</sub> capture.

The liquefaction process also involves the use of a solvent, such as amine solutions, to absorb the CO<sub>2</sub> from the flue gas. The solvent is then heated to release the CO<sub>2</sub>, which is then liquefied. The solvent is then reused in the process, reducing the overall cost and environmental impact.

The liquefaction process is a key component of the retrofitting of existing power plants. It allows for the effective capture and storage of CO<sub>2</sub>, reducing the environmental impact of power plants. However, it also presents significant challenges, including high energy requirements and the need for specialized equipment and expertise.

In the following sections, we will delve deeper into the various aspects of CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction, including the different methods used, the energy requirements, and the challenges and opportunities associated with this process.

#### 12.2b CO2 Liquefaction Processes

The liquefaction of CO<sub>2</sub> involves a series of steps that are designed to convert the gas into a liquid form. These steps are typically carried out in a closed-loop system, with the CO<sub>2</sub> being continuously recycled and reused. The following are the key steps involved in the liquefaction process:

1. **Compression:** The first step in the liquefaction process is to compress the CO<sub>2</sub> gas. This is typically achieved using a centrifugal compressor, which increases the pressure and reduces the volume of the gas. The compression process also increases the temperature of the gas, which is crucial for the subsequent liquefaction step.

2. **Cooling:** The compressed CO<sub>2</sub> gas is then cooled to a very low temperature, typically below -78Â°C. This is typically achieved using a heat exchanger, which transfers the heat from the CO<sub>2</sub> gas to a secondary fluid, such as water or a refrigerant. The cooling process reduces the temperature of the gas, making it more likely to liquefy.

3. **Liquefaction:** Once the CO<sub>2</sub> gas has been cooled and compressed, it is passed through a valve that further reduces its pressure. This causes the gas to expand and cool further, leading to the formation of liquid CO<sub>2</sub>. The liquefaction process is highly energy-intensive, requiring significant amounts of electricity to drive the compressors and expanders.

4. **Storage or Transportation:** The liquid CO<sub>2</sub> is then stored or transported for further processing. The liquid CO<sub>2</sub> can be stored in underground reservoirs, where it can be stored for long periods of time. Alternatively, it can be transported by pipeline or by truck to a central processing facility.

The liquefaction process is highly energy-intensive, requiring significant amounts of electricity to drive the compressors and expanders. However, the energy requirements can be reduced by using a hybrid system that combines the Brayton cycle with other methods, such as the Kalina cycle or the Rankine cycle. These hybrid systems can achieve higher efficiencies and lower energy requirements, making them more attractive for large-scale CO<sub>2</sub> capture.

The liquefaction process also involves the use of a solvent, such as amine solutions, to absorb the CO<sub>2</sub> from the flue gas. The solvent is then heated to release the CO<sub>2</sub>, which is then liquefied. The solvent is then reused in the process, reducing the overall cost and environmental impact.

#### 12.2c Applications of CO2 Liquefaction

The liquefaction of CO<sub>2</sub> has a wide range of applications in the field of chemical engineering. The liquefied CO<sub>2</sub> can be used in various processes, including:

1. **Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS):** The primary application of CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction is in carbon capture and storage. The liquefied CO<sub>2</sub> can be stored in underground reservoirs, where it can be stored for long periods of time. This process helps in reducing the amount of CO<sub>2</sub> released into the atmosphere, thereby reducing the impact of climate change.

2. **Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR):** Liquefied CO<sub>2</sub> can also be used in enhanced oil recovery. The CO<sub>2</sub> is injected into oil reservoirs, where it displaces the oil and allows it to be extracted more easily. This process can increase the amount of oil that can be extracted from a reservoir, while also reducing the amount of CO<sub>2</sub> released into the atmosphere.

3. **Chemical Industry:** Liquefied CO<sub>2</sub> is also used in various chemical processes. For example, it is used in the production of urea, a key component in fertilizers. The CO<sub>2</sub> is reacted with ammonia to form urea, a process known as the Haber-Bosch process.

4. **Food and Beverage Industry:** Liquefied CO<sub>2</sub> is used in the food and beverage industry for processes such as carbonation of drinks and freezing of foods. The CO<sub>2</sub> is also used in the production of dry ice, which is used for cooling and preserving perishable goods.

The liquefaction of CO<sub>2</sub> is a complex process that requires careful control and monitoring. However, with the right equipment and processes, it can be a highly effective way of managing CO<sub>2</sub> emissions and reducing the impact of climate change.

We have explored the various aspects of this process, including the challenges faced, the strategies employed, and the potential benefits that can be realized. We have also examined the role of CO<sub>2</sub> capture in this process, and how it can contribute to the overall efficiency and sustainability of power generation.

CO<sub>2</sub> capture plays a crucial role in this process. This can help to mitigate the effects of climate change, and contribute to the global efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

In conclusion, the retrofitting of existing power plants is a complex but essential process. It requires a comprehensive understanding of the plant's existing infrastructure, the identification of areas for improvement, and the implementation of suitable technologies and strategies. CO<sub>2</sub> capture plays a crucial role in this process, offering a means to reduce the environmental impact of power generation.

This chapter, "Carbon Capture from Flue Gas," delves into the critical process of capturing CO<sub>2</sub> from flue gas, a byproduct of power generation.

The chapter begins by providing a comprehensive overview of the carbon capture process, explaining its importance in mitigating climate change. It then delves into the specifics of capturing CO<sub>2</sub> from flue gas, a complex process that involves several stages and technologies. The chapter will also discuss the various methods of carbon capture, including post-combustion capture, pre-combustion capture, and oxy-fuel combustion.

The chapter will also explore the challenges and opportunities associated with carbon capture from flue gas. While the process is complex and energy-intensive, it offers a promising solution to the problem of CO<sub>2</sub> emissions. The chapter will discuss the current state of the art in carbon capture technology, as well as the future prospects for this field.

Finally, the chapter will discuss the role of chemical engineering in carbon capture from flue gas. Chemical engineers play a crucial role in designing, optimizing, and operating carbon capture systems. The chapter will provide a glimpse into the fascinating world of chemical engineering, and how it is being used to address one of the most pressing environmental challenges of our time.

In conclusion, this chapter aims to provide a comprehensive guide to carbon capture from flue gas, covering the principles, methods, challenges, and opportunities of this critical process. It is our hope that this chapter will serve as a valuable resource for students, researchers, and professionals in the field of chemical engineering.




### Section: 12.2b Applications of CO2 Liquefaction

The liquefaction of CO<sub>2</sub> has a wide range of applications in the field of chemical engineering. It is a crucial process in the retrofitting of existing power plants, as it allows for the effective capture and storage of CO<sub>2</sub>. However, the applications of CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction extend beyond power plant retrofitting.

#### 12.2b.1 Carbon Capture and Storage

The primary application of CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction is in carbon capture and storage (CCS). CCS is a technology that aims to reduce the environmental impact of power plants by capturing the CO<sub>2</sub> emitted during combustion and storing it in geological formations or concrete. The liquefaction of CO<sub>2</sub> is a key step in this process, as it allows for the CO<sub>2</sub> to be easily transported and stored.

CCS technology can be applied to a variety of power plants, including coal-fired, natural gas, and biomass-fired plants. By retrofitting these plants with CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction and storage systems, the environmental impact of these power plants can be significantly reduced.

#### 12.2b.2 Enhanced Oil Recovery

Another important application of CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction is in enhanced oil recovery (EOR). EOR is a process used to extract additional oil from reservoirs after primary and secondary recovery methods have been exhausted. In EOR, CO<sub>2</sub> is injected into the reservoir to displace the oil and facilitate its extraction.

The liquefaction of CO<sub>2</sub> is crucial in this process, as it allows for the CO<sub>2</sub> to be easily transported and injected into the reservoir. Additionally, the liquefaction process can be used to remove impurities from the CO<sub>2</sub>, making it more suitable for use in EOR.

#### 12.2b.3 Other Applications

CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction also has applications in other areas of chemical engineering, such as in the production of carbonated beverages, the extraction of essential oils, and the synthesis of various chemicals. The liquefaction process can be used to remove impurities from the CO<sub>2</sub>, making it suitable for these applications.

In conclusion, the liquefaction of CO<sub>2</sub> has a wide range of applications in the field of chemical engineering. From carbon capture and storage to enhanced oil recovery, this process plays a crucial role in various industries. As technology continues to advance, it is likely that new applications for CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction will be discovered.




### Section: 12.2c Case Studies in CO2 Liquefaction

In this section, we will explore some case studies that demonstrate the practical applications of CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction. These case studies will provide a deeper understanding of the challenges and solutions encountered in the process of liquefying CO<sub>2</sub>.

#### 12.2c.1 Case Study 1: Retrofitting of a Coal-Fired Power Plant

A coal-fired power plant in the United States was retrofitted with a CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction system as part of a carbon capture and storage project. The plant had a capacity of 500 MW and was equipped with a flue gas desulfurization system. The CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction system was installed downstream of the desulfurization system.

The liquefaction system consisted of a series of heat exchangers, a compressor, and a liquefaction vessel. The flue gas from the power plant was first cooled in a heat exchanger using cooling water. The gas was then compressed to a pressure of 10 MPa. The compressed gas was then liquefied in a liquefaction vessel by cooling it to a temperature of -78Â°C. The liquid CO<sub>2</sub> was then stored in an underground reservoir.

The project was successful in capturing and storing over 90% of the CO<sub>2</sub> emitted by the power plant. The liquefaction system was able to handle the varying flow rates and compositions of the flue gas, demonstrating the flexibility of the CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction process.

#### 12.2c.2 Case Study 2: Enhanced Oil Recovery in a Petroleum Refinery

A petroleum refinery in the Middle East was facing depleting oil reserves and was looking for ways to increase oil recovery. The refinery decided to implement a CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction system for enhanced oil recovery.

The CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction system was installed in the refinery's oil reservoir. The system consisted of a series of heat exchangers, a compressor, and a liquefaction vessel. The CO<sub>2</sub> was injected into the reservoir at a pressure of 10 MPa and a temperature of -78Â°C. The CO<sub>2</sub> displaced the oil, facilitating its extraction.

The project was successful in increasing oil recovery by over 20%. The CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction process was able to handle the high pressures and temperatures in the reservoir, demonstrating the robustness of the process.

These case studies highlight the versatility and effectiveness of CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction in various applications. They also underscore the importance of process design in ensuring the successful implementation of CO<sub>2</sub> liquefaction systems.




### Section: 12.3 Oxyfiring:

Oxyfiring is a process used in power plants to reduce the amount of nitrogen in the combustion process, thereby reducing the amount of NO<sub>x</sub> emissions. This process involves the use of pure oxygen instead of air for combustion. Oxyfiring can be used in both new and existing power plants, making it a versatile and effective method for reducing emissions.

#### 12.3a Introduction to Oxyfiring

Oxyfiring is a process that involves the use of pure oxygen instead of air for combustion in power plants. This process is particularly useful in coal-fired power plants, where the use of oxygen can increase the efficiency of the combustion process and reduce the amount of NO<sub>x</sub> emissions.

The process of oxyfiring involves the use of a gas generator to produce pure oxygen. This oxygen is then used to replace the nitrogen in the air used for combustion. The resulting mixture is then used to combust the fuel, in this case, coal. The use of pure oxygen allows for a more efficient combustion process, as it has a higher oxygen content than air. This results in a hotter and more complete combustion, leading to lower emissions of NO<sub>x</sub>.

One of the main advantages of oxyfiring is its ability to be retrofitted into existing power plants. This makes it a cost-effective solution for reducing emissions in older power plants. Additionally, oxyfiring can also be used in new power plants, providing a cleaner and more efficient method of combustion.

In the next section, we will explore the different types of oxyfiring systems and their applications in power plants.

#### 12.3b Types of Oxyfiring Systems

There are two main types of oxyfiring systems: direct and indirect. Direct oxyfiring involves the use of pure oxygen for combustion, while indirect oxyfiring uses a mixture of oxygen and steam.

Direct oxyfiring is more commonly used in coal-fired power plants. In this system, the coal is pulverized and injected into a combustor along with pure oxygen. The resulting combustion produces a high-temperature and high-pressure gas, which is then used to drive a turbine and generate electricity. The main advantage of direct oxyfiring is its simplicity and efficiency, but it also requires a high level of maintenance and monitoring due to the high temperatures and pressures involved.

Indirect oxyfiring, on the other hand, uses a mixture of oxygen and steam for combustion. This system is more commonly used in gas-fired power plants. In indirect oxyfiring, the fuel is first reacted with steam in a reformer to produce a hydrogen-rich gas. This gas is then combusted with oxygen to produce electricity. The main advantage of indirect oxyfiring is its lower operating temperatures and pressures, making it more suitable for retrofitting into existing power plants. However, it also requires a more complex system and may not be as efficient as direct oxyfiring.

#### 12.3c Case Studies in Oxyfiring

To further illustrate the effectiveness of oxyfiring, let's take a look at some case studies.

One example is the retrofitting of an existing coal-fired power plant in the United States. The plant was equipped with a direct oxyfiring system, which resulted in a 50% reduction in NO<sub>x</sub> emissions. This was achieved by replacing the nitrogen in the air with pure oxygen, leading to a more complete combustion and lower emissions.

Another case study is the use of indirect oxyfiring in a gas-fired power plant in Europe. The plant was able to reduce its NO<sub>x</sub> emissions by 80% by using a mixture of oxygen and steam for combustion. This was achieved by the lower operating temperatures and pressures, making it more suitable for retrofitting into existing power plants.

These case studies demonstrate the effectiveness of oxyfiring in reducing emissions in power plants. By using pure oxygen for combustion, oxyfiring can significantly reduce NO<sub>x</sub> emissions, making it a valuable tool in the fight against air pollution.

### Subsection: 12.4a Introduction to Polygeneration

Polygeneration is a technology that allows for the simultaneous production of electricity, heat, and other products from a single energy source. This technology is particularly relevant in the context of power plant retrofitting, as it offers a means to optimize energy usage and reduce waste.

#### 12.4a.1 Basics of Polygeneration

Polygeneration involves the use of a primary energy source, such as coal, natural gas, or nuclear energy, to generate electricity. However, instead of simply using the energy source to produce electricity, polygeneration technologies also capture and utilize the waste heat and byproducts of the electricity generation process.

For example, in a coal-fired power plant, the coal is burned to produce steam, which is then used to drive a turbine and generate electricity. However, in a polygeneration system, the waste heat from the steam is captured and used for other purposes, such as heating or cooling buildings, or for use in industrial processes.

#### 12.4a.2 Types of Polygeneration

There are several types of polygeneration systems, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. Some of the most common types include:

- **Cogeneration:** This is the most basic type of polygeneration, where electricity and heat are produced simultaneously from a single energy source. Cogeneration systems are commonly used in industrial processes, where the heat can be used for various purposes, such as heating or cooling, or for use in chemical reactions.

- **Trigeneration:** Trigeneration systems produce electricity, heat, and cooling from a single energy source. This is particularly relevant in tropical regions, where cooling is often required in addition to heating and electricity. Trigeneration systems can be more complex and expensive to implement, but they offer the advantage of maximizing energy usage and minimizing waste.

- **Quadgeneration:** Quadgeneration systems produce electricity, heat, cooling, and desalinated water from a single energy source. This is particularly relevant in coastal regions, where desalinated water is often required. Quadgeneration systems are even more complex and expensive than trigeneration systems, but they offer the advantage of providing a comprehensive range of energy and water services.

#### 12.4a.3 Benefits of Polygeneration

Polygeneration offers several benefits, including:

- **Energy efficiency:** By utilizing the waste heat and byproducts of the electricity generation process, polygeneration systems can achieve high energy efficiencies. This can result in significant cost savings and reduced environmental impact.

- **Reliability:** Polygeneration systems are often more reliable than traditional power generation systems, as they can provide both electricity and heat simultaneously. This can be particularly beneficial in industrial processes, where a reliable supply of both electricity and heat is crucial.

- **Environmental benefits:** By reducing waste and maximizing energy usage, polygeneration systems can significantly reduce their environmental impact. This includes reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, as well as reductions in water and land use.

In the following sections, we will explore these types of polygeneration in more detail, and discuss their applications in power plant retrofitting.




### Subsection: 12.4b Applications of Polygeneration

Polygeneration systems have a wide range of applications, particularly in the context of power plant retrofitting. These systems can be used to optimize energy usage and reduce waste in various industries, including:

- **Power plants:** As mentioned earlier, polygeneration systems are particularly relevant in the context of power plant retrofitting. By capturing and utilizing the waste heat and byproducts of the electricity generation process, these systems can significantly improve the efficiency of power plants.

- **Industrial processes:** Many industrial processes require both heat and electricity. By implementing a polygeneration system, these industries can optimize their energy usage and reduce waste. For example, in the chemical industry, polygeneration systems can be used to produce electricity, heat, and cooling for various processes.

- **Building heating and cooling:** In both residential and commercial buildings, heating and cooling are often required. Polygeneration systems can be used to provide these services more efficiently, by capturing and utilizing the waste heat from electricity generation.

- **Renewable energy systems:** Polygeneration systems can also be used in conjunction with renewable energy sources, such as solar or wind power. By capturing and utilizing the waste heat from these sources, the efficiency of the system can be improved, making it more viable for widespread use.

In conclusion, polygeneration systems offer a promising solution for optimizing energy usage and reducing waste in various industries. As technology continues to advance, it is likely that these systems will play an increasingly important role in the future of energy production.

### Conclusion

In this chapter, we have delved into the complex and intricate world of power plant retrofitting, a critical aspect of integrated chemical engineering. We have explored the various factors that need to be considered when retrofitting a power plant, including the type of power plant, the reasons for retrofitting, and the potential benefits and challenges that come with the process. 

We have also discussed the importance of careful planning and design in power plant retrofitting, emphasizing the need for a comprehensive understanding of the plant's current state, its future needs, and the available technologies and resources. 

In addition, we have highlighted the role of CO2 capture in power plant retrofitting, a crucial aspect of reducing carbon emissions and mitigating climate change. We have discussed the various methods of CO2 capture, their advantages and disadvantages, and their potential impact on the overall efficiency and cost-effectiveness of the retrofitting process.

Overall, power plant retrofitting is a complex and multifaceted process that requires a deep understanding of chemical engineering principles, a keen eye for detail, and a strategic approach to planning and design. It is a critical component of our efforts to ensure a sustainable and environmentally friendly future.

### Subsection: 12.5a Basics of Water Gas Shift Reaction

The Water Gas Shift (WGS) reaction is a crucial process in the retrofitting of existing power plants. It is an equilibrium reaction that involves the conversion of carbon monoxide (CO) and water (H<sub>2</sub>O) to carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) and hydrogen (H<sub>2</sub>). This reaction is exothermic, with a Î”H<=> of -41.1 kJ/mol and an adiabatic temperature rise of 8â€“10Â Â°C per percent CO converted to CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>.

The WGS reaction is primarily used in the production of hydrogen, which can be further used for the production of methanol and ammonia. The most common catalysts used in the WGS reaction are the High Temperature Shift (HTS) catalyst and the Low Temperature Shift (LTS) catalyst. The HTS catalyst consists of iron oxide stabilized by chromium oxide, while the LTS catalyst is based on copper.

The equilibrium constant for the WGS reaction is given by:

$$
K_p = \frac{p_{H_2} \cdot p_{CO_2}}{p_{CO} \cdot p_{H_2O}}
$$

where $p$ represents the partial pressure of the respective gases. The equilibrium constant can be expressed in terms of the temperature as:

$$
K_p = K_p^e \cdot e^{\frac{4577.8K}{T-4.22}}
$$

where $K_p^e$ is the equilibrium constant at the reference temperature.

The WGS reaction is an essential component of polygeneration systems, which are used in the retrofitting of existing power plants. These systems capture and utilize the waste heat from the electricity generation process, resulting in significant improvements in efficiency and a reduction in the plant's carbon footprint.

In the next section, we will explore some real-world case studies that demonstrate the application of the WGS reaction in power plant retrofitting.

### Subsection: 12.5b Applications of Water Gas Shift Reaction

The Water Gas Shift (WGS) reaction has a wide range of applications in the field of chemical engineering, particularly in the retrofitting of existing power plants. The WGS reaction is used to produce hydrogen, which is a key component in the production of methanol and ammonia. 

#### Methanol Production

Methanol is a versatile chemical that is used in a variety of industries, including as a fuel, a solvent, and a raw material in the production of other chemicals. The WGS reaction is used in the production of methanol from natural gas. The natural gas is first reformed to produce hydrogen and carbon monoxide, which are then reacted in the WGS reaction to produce additional hydrogen and carbon dioxide. The hydrogen is then used in the Sabatier reaction to produce methane, which is then converted to methanol.

#### Ammonia Production

Ammonia is a key component in the production of fertilizers and other nitrogen-containing chemicals. The WGS reaction is used in the production of ammonia from natural gas. The natural gas is first reformed to produce hydrogen and carbon monoxide, which are then reacted in the WGS reaction to produce additional hydrogen and carbon dioxide. The hydrogen is then used in the Haber-Bosch process to produce ammonia.

#### Power Plant Retrofitting

The WGS reaction is also used in the retrofitting of existing power plants. The WGS reaction is used to convert the carbon monoxide in the flue gas to carbon dioxide and hydrogen, which can then be used to produce electricity. This process not only increases the efficiency of the power plant, but also reduces its carbon footprint by reducing the amount of carbon monoxide emitted.

In conclusion, the Water Gas Shift reaction plays a crucial role in a variety of chemical processes, making it an essential topic for any comprehensive guide to chemical engineering. In the next section, we will explore the challenges and considerations associated with implementing the WGS reaction in existing power plants.

### Subsection: 12.5c Challenges in Water Gas Shift Reaction

The Water Gas Shift (WGS) reaction, while being a crucial process in the production of hydrogen and the retrofitting of existing power plants, is not without its challenges. These challenges can be broadly categorized into three areas: reaction kinetics, catalyst deactivation, and process integration.

#### Reaction Kinetics

The WGS reaction is an equilibrium reaction, and as such, it is influenced by the Le Chatelier's principle. Any changes in the system can shift the equilibrium, affecting the yield of the desired products. The reaction is also highly temperature-dependent, with the equilibrium constant increasing with temperature. This can make it difficult to control the reaction conditions to achieve the desired product yield.

#### Catalyst Deactivation

The WGS reaction is typically catalyzed by iron oxide or copper-based catalysts. However, these catalysts can deactivate over time due to the formation of carbonaceous deposits. This can reduce the efficiency of the reaction and increase the cost of operation. Regular catalyst regeneration or replacement is necessary to maintain the efficiency of the WGS reaction.

#### Process Integration

The WGS reaction is often integrated into larger processes, such as methanol or ammonia production. This requires careful design and control to ensure that the WGS reaction operates efficiently and does not adversely affect the overall process. For example, in methanol production, the WGS reaction is followed by the Sabatier reaction, which can consume the hydrogen produced by the WGS reaction. This can limit the efficiency of the WGS reaction and require additional hydrogen to be supplied.

Despite these challenges, the WGS reaction remains a key process in chemical engineering. Ongoing research is focused on developing new catalysts, improving reaction kinetics, and optimizing process integration to overcome these challenges and improve the efficiency and sustainability of the WGS reaction.

### Subsection: 12.5b Applications of Water Gas Shift Reaction

The Water Gas Shift (WGS) reaction is a crucial process in the retrofitting of existing power plants. It is primarily used in the production of hydrogen, which can be further used for the production of methanol and ammonia. The WGS reaction is also used in the production of syngas, a mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide, which is used as a fuel in gas turbines and internal combustion engines.

#### 12.5b.1 Fuel Cells

The WGS reaction plays a critical role in the efficiency of fuel cells. In fuel cells susceptible to carbon monoxide poisoning, such as the proton-exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell, the WGS reaction helps to reduce the concentration of carbon monoxide. This is because the WGS reaction increases hydrogen production, which in turn reduces the concentration of carbon monoxide. This application of the WGS reaction is particularly important in the development of a hydrogen economy, where fuel cells are expected to play a significant role.

However, the development of WGS catalysts for fuel cell applications is an area of current research interest. Current commercial catalysts used in industrial water gas shift processes are not compatible with fuel cell applications. This is due to the high demand for clean fuel and the critical role of the WGS reaction in hydrogen fuel cells. Developing a catalyst that can overcome these limitations is relevant to the implementation of a hydrogen economy.

#### 12.5b.2 Sorption Enhanced Water Gas Shift

The WGS reaction is also used in combination with the solid adsorption of CO<sub>2</sub> in the sorption enhanced water gas shift (SEWGS). This process is used to produce a high pressure hydrogen stream from syngas. The SEWGS process is particularly useful in the retrofitting of existing power plants, as it allows for the efficient production of hydrogen from syngas.

#### 12.5b.3 Reaction Conditions

The equilibrium of the WGS reaction shows a significant temperature dependence, with the equilibrium constant decreasing with an increase in temperature. This means that higher hydrogen formation is observed at lower temperatures. The WGS reaction is also exothermic, with a Î”H<=> of -41.1 kJ/mol and an adiabatic temperature rise of 8â€“10Â Â°C per percent CO converted to CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>.

The WGS reaction is primarily catalyzed by iron oxide stabilized by chromium oxide (High Temperature Shift, HTS) and copper (Low Temperature Shift, LTS). The equilibrium constant for the WGS reaction is given by:

$$
K_p = \frac{p_{H_2} \cdot p_{CO_2}}{p_{CO} \cdot p_{H_2O}}
$$

where $p$ represents the partial pressure of the respective gases. The equilibrium constant can be expressed in terms of the temperature as:

$$
K_p = K_p^e \cdot e^{\frac{4577.8K}{T-4.22}}
$$

where $K_p^e$ is the equilibrium constant at the reference temperature.




### Subsection: 12.5c Case Studies in Water Gas Shift Reaction

In this section, we will explore some case studies that demonstrate the application of the Water Gas Shift (WGS) reaction in the retrofitting of existing power plants. These case studies will provide a practical perspective on the challenges and solutions associated with implementing the WGS reaction in real-world scenarios.

#### 12.5c.1 Case Study 1: Retrofitting of a Coal-Fired Power Plant

A coal-fired power plant in the United States was retrofitted to incorporate the WGS reaction as part of its process design. The plant was equipped with a high temperature shift (HTS) reactor and a low temperature shift (LTS) reactor, similar to the industrial scale water gas shift reaction. The HTS reactor was operated at a temperature of 310Â°C to 450Â°C, while the LTS reactor was operated at a lower temperature to achieve a carbon monoxide content of less than 1%.

The retrofitting process faced several challenges, including the need for extensive modifications to the plant's existing infrastructure and the high cost of the WGS catalysts. However, the benefits of the WGS reaction, such as the production of hydrogen for fuel cells and the efficient production of syngas, outweighed these challenges.

#### 12.5c.2 Case Study 2: Retrofitting of a Natural Gas-Fired Power Plant

A natural gas-fired power plant in Europe was also retrofitted to incorporate the WGS reaction. Unlike the coal-fired power plant, this plant did not require a HTS reactor as it already had a low carbon monoxide content in its syngas. However, the plant did need to install a LTS reactor to further reduce the carbon monoxide content.

The retrofitting process for this plant was less complex than that of the coal-fired power plant, but it still faced challenges such as the need for new equipment and the high cost of the WGS catalysts. However, the benefits of the WGS reaction, such as the production of hydrogen for fuel cells and the efficient production of syngas, made the retrofitting process worthwhile.

#### 12.5c.3 Lessons Learned

These case studies highlight the importance of careful planning and consideration when retrofitting existing power plants with the WGS reaction. They also underscore the need for ongoing research and development to improve the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of the WGS reaction.

In conclusion, the WGS reaction plays a crucial role in the retrofitting of existing power plants. It offers numerous benefits, such as the production of hydrogen for fuel cells and the efficient production of syngas. However, it also presents challenges that must be carefully managed to ensure a successful retrofitting process.

### Subsection: 12.6a Introduction to Retrofitting

Retrofitting is a critical aspect of process design in chemical engineering, particularly in the context of existing power plants. It involves the modification of existing systems to improve their performance, efficiency, or safety. This process is often necessary when new technologies or regulations require changes to the system, or when the system is not performing as expected.

Retrofitting can be a complex and challenging process, requiring a deep understanding of the system, its components, and the changes being made. It often involves careful planning, design, and testing to ensure that the modifications are effective and safe.

#### 12.6a.1 Retrofitting of Existing Power Plants

The retrofitting of existing power plants is a common application of retrofitting in chemical engineering. Power plants are complex systems that generate electricity from various sources, such as coal, natural gas, or nuclear energy. Over time, these systems can become outdated, inefficient, or unsafe, making retrofitting necessary.

Retrofitting of power plants can involve a variety of modifications, including the installation of new equipment, the upgrade of existing equipment, or the implementation of new processes. For example, a power plant might be retrofitted to reduce its carbon emissions, improve its energy efficiency, or enhance its safety.

#### 12.6a.2 Challenges and Solutions in Retrofitting

Retrofitting of existing power plants can present several challenges. These can include the complexity of the system, the need for extensive modifications, and the potential for disruption during the retrofitting process. However, these challenges can be addressed with careful planning, design, and execution.

For instance, the use of advanced technologies, such as Building Information Modeling (BIM), can help in the planning and design stages of retrofitting. BIM allows for the creation of a digital representation of the power plant, which can be used to visualize the modifications, identify potential clashes, and optimize the retrofitting process.

Furthermore, the use of lean product development principles can help in the execution stage of retrofitting. Lean product development emphasizes the elimination of waste and the maximization of value, which can be particularly beneficial in the context of retrofitting, where every modification must be carefully considered and executed.

In conclusion, retrofitting is a critical aspect of process design in chemical engineering, particularly in the context of existing power plants. It involves careful planning, design, and execution, and can be aided by advanced technologies and principles such as BIM and lean product development.




### Subsection: 12.6b Techniques for Retrofitting

Retrofitting of existing power plants can be achieved through various techniques. These techniques can be broadly categorized into two types: incremental and radical.

#### 12.6b.1 Incremental Retrofitting

Incremental retrofitting involves making small, incremental changes to the system. This approach is often used when the system is still functioning, but could benefit from some improvements. Incremental retrofitting can be a cost-effective way to improve the system's performance, efficiency, or safety.

For example, in a power plant, incremental retrofitting might involve upgrading individual components, such as a boiler or a turbine, to improve their performance. This can be done without disrupting the entire system, which can be beneficial for maintaining the plant's operation during the retrofitting process.

#### 12.6b.2 Radical Retrofitting

Radical retrofitting, on the other hand, involves making significant changes to the system. This approach is often used when the system is not functioning as expected, or when new technologies or regulations require a more comprehensive change.

Radical retrofitting can involve the installation of new equipment, the replacement of existing equipment, or the implementation of new processes. For example, a power plant might be retrofitted with a new type of turbine, or with a new cooling system, or with a new process for generating electricity.

Radical retrofitting can be a more disruptive process than incremental retrofitting, as it often involves significant changes to the system. However, it can also lead to more significant improvements in performance, efficiency, or safety.

#### 12.6b.3 Hybrid Retrofitting

Hybrid retrofitting combines elements of both incremental and radical retrofitting. It involves making a combination of small, incremental changes and significant, radical changes to the system. This approach can be particularly effective when the system requires both minor improvements and major upgrades.

For example, in a power plant, hybrid retrofitting might involve upgrading individual components, such as a boiler or a turbine, while also implementing a new process for generating electricity. This can be a cost-effective way to improve the system's performance, efficiency, and safety.

In conclusion, retrofitting of existing power plants is a complex process that requires careful planning and execution. By understanding the different techniques available, engineers can make informed decisions about the best approach for each specific case.

### Conclusion

In this chapter, we have delved into the complex and critical process of retrofitting existing power plants. We have explored the various aspects of this process, including the challenges faced, the strategies employed, and the benefits accrued. The chapter has provided a comprehensive guide to understanding and implementing retrofitting in power plants, with a focus on CO2 capture and process design.

The chapter has highlighted the importance of retrofitting in the context of environmental sustainability and energy efficiency. It has underscored the need for chemical engineers to be at the forefront of this process, leveraging their expertise in process design and CO2 capture to ensure the successful retrofitting of power plants.

In conclusion, retrofitting of existing power plants is a complex but crucial process that requires a deep understanding of chemical engineering principles. It is a process that holds great promise for the future of energy production, offering a viable pathway to a more sustainable and efficient energy system.

The project also resulted in significant cost savings, as the plant was able to sell the captured carbon dioxide for use in enhanced oil recovery.

#### 12.7a Introduction to Chemical Looping Combustor

Chemical looping combustion (CLC) is a promising technology for the retrofitting of existing power plants. It offers several advantages over traditional combustion methods, including improved efficiency and the ability to capture nearly all of the CO<sub>2</sub> generated by the system. This section will provide an overview of CLC, including its principles, advantages, and potential applications.

##### Principles of Chemical Looping Combustion

CLC involves two redox reactions: one in an air reactor and one in a fuel reactor. In the air reactor, an oxygen carrier material, such as nickel oxide, is reduced by atmospheric oxygen to nickel. This oxygen-rich material is then transported to the fuel reactor, where it oxidizes the fuel, such as coal or biomass, to generate heat and electricity. The resulting flue gas from the fuel reactor contains nearly all of the CO<sub>2</sub> generated by the system, along with water vapor. This flue gas can be easily separated from the oxygen-rich material, which can then be returned to the air reactor to repeat the process.

##### Advantages of Chemical Looping Combustion

One of the main advantages of CLC is its ability to capture nearly all of the CO<sub>2</sub> generated by the system. This is achieved by the two separate flue gas streams generated by the air and fuel reactors. The air reactor flue gas, consisting of atmospheric nitrogen and residual oxygen, can be discharged to the atmosphere, causing minimal CO<sub>2</sub> pollution. The reducer exit gas, containing almost all of the CO<sub>2</sub> generated by the system, can be easily removed from the fuel reactor. This gives CLC clear benefits when compared with competing carbon capture technologies, as the latter generally involve a significant energy penalty associated with either post combustion scrubbing systems or the work input required for air separation plants.

##### Applications of Chemical Looping Combustion

CLC has been successfully demonstrated in several pilot plants, with a total operational experience of more than 9000 hours. It has been used with gaseous fuels since 2003 and with solid fuels since 2006. The technology is currently being developed for commercial application, with the potential to retrofit existing power plants and reduce their carbon emissions.

In the next section, we will delve deeper into the principles and applications of CLC, exploring its potential for large-scale implementation and its role in the future of energy production.

#### 12.7b Design of Chemical Looping Combustor

The design of a chemical looping combustor (CLC) involves careful consideration of several factors, including the choice of oxygen carrier material, the design of the reactors, and the control of the combustion process.

##### Oxygen Carrier Material

The choice of oxygen carrier material is crucial in the design of a CLC. The material must be able to undergo repeated redox cycles without degradation. Nickel oxide has been used in many CLC demonstrations due to its high oxygen storage capacity and its ability to undergo repeated redox cycles. However, other materials, such as iron oxide and cobalt oxide, have also been proposed and tested.

##### Reactor Design

The design of the reactors in a CLC is also important. The air reactor must be designed to ensure efficient reduction of the oxygen carrier material, while the fuel reactor must be designed to ensure efficient oxidation of the fuel. The reactors must also be designed to allow for the efficient separation of the two flue gas streams.

##### Control of Combustion Process

The control of the combustion process is a critical aspect of CLC design. The oxygen carrier material must be transported between the air reactor and the fuel reactor in a controlled manner. The combustion process must also be controlled to ensure efficient fuel oxidation and to minimize the formation of unwanted byproducts.

##### Advantages of Chemical Looping Combustor

The design of a CLC offers several advantages over traditional combustion methods. The ability to capture nearly all of the CO<sub>2</sub> generated by the system, the potential for improved efficiency, and the ability to use a variety of fuels are just a few of the advantages that make CLC a promising technology for the retrofitting of existing power plants.

In the next section, we will delve deeper into the design of a CLC, exploring the various design considerations in more detail.
